Brokoli elevates your music discovery experience to a whole new level.

  • Timeline 12 Weeks
  • Team Myself
  • Role Product design, UX design, User research

Project Vision

Spotify has a recommendation feature that focuses on songs discovery. However, this feature doesn't have an enough customization features yet. By utilizing the songs audio features provided by Spotify Web API, this project is focused on creating song recommendation app based on audio similarity and songs novelty. Where the user can adjust the audio features filters as much as they like and get the exact recommendations based on their specific preferences.

Kickoff

In Brokoli's design process, we opted for a goal-directed design approach that helped us move along through the timeline smoothly. Qualitative research methods proved to be the most effective during the design process, most notably questionnaire distribution and usability testing sessions. Whenever we encounter an issue that we are trying to solve, it's smart to build a good foundation. In Brokoli's case, we did this by asking some generic but useful internal questions.
"Who is our primary audience?"
"What are the challenges we will face moving forward?"
“What makes it different from existing products?“
"Is there specific knowledge field to know?"
“What do our users need the most in a product like this?”
“What do our users need the most in a product like this?”

1/7 Research Insight

Surveys and interviews with 10 participants who currently are active users of Spotify.
01
Most users feel that Spotify's autoplay feature plays songs that tend to be repetitive.
02
Lack of customization features in Spotify song search system.
01
The Spotify discovery feature has a fairly broad scope of classification.

2/7 Preliminary Ideation

Affinity mapping used to identify not only the general scope of Brokoli, but to decide which direction the product want to proceed. This was a form of brainstorming during the kickoff period that proved to be very helpful in setting up the foundation for the rest of our process.

3/7 Meet The Users

Summary personas captured primary, secondary, excluded perspectives from research insights.

4/7 Journey Map

Five steps and mood mappings imagined persona use of concept.

5/7 System Architecture

Used to facilitate decisions for dynamic task flow interactions.

6/7 Lo-Fi Ideation

Low fidelity sketches are used to put some rough ideas on top of papers. This process helped me to spark ideas and translate those rough ideas into a vivid product skeletons.

7/8 Preliminary Wireframes

Creating a higher fidelity but still fairly preliminary version of our wireframes, we were able to workout some of the technical issues that would not be viable in Brokoli. It was important for us to start big and scale down so that we could work around the features that we really wanted to have, rather than working upwards and missing something that would've been really cool to see as a user.

Final Design

Style Guide

For the color tones of Brokoli, I decided to match it with Spotify identic green. It aims to provide familiarity to the Spotify users. We utilizated color sparingly throughout the app to convey which elements were interactable and should be paid attention to within the product. We also opted to use the typefaces Neue Montreal within the interface as they played the pivotal role of making the clean and trendy environment we had built in Brokoli's interface.

Takeaways

Brokoli as a concept is something that I feel music listener would greatly benefit from. Brokoli works as a Spotify companion and brings additional value to the users that they couldn't find in the Spotify itself. The primary difficulty I had while designing this product was to make users to feel engaged and convinced to install the product eventhough this product just works as a companion app of Spotify. I feel that although there may be a better solution out there, I designed an experience that works well for most users.
